greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Irregular triangle T(n,k), n>=1, 1<=k<=A186971(n), read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of subsets of {1, 2, ..., n} containing n and having <=k pairwise coprime elements.
comment: T(n,k) = T(n,k-1) for k>A186971(n). The triangle contains all values of T up to the last element of each row that is different from its predecessor.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..200, flattened
example: T(5,3) = 10 because there are 10 subsets of {1,2,3,4,5} containing n and having <=3 pairwise coprime elements: {5}, {1,5}, {2,5}, {3,5}, {4,5}, {1,2,5}, {1,3,5}, {1,4,5}, {2,3,5}, {3,4,5}.
maple: s:= proc(m,r) option remember; mul(`if`(i<r, i, 1), i=factorset(m)) end:
a:= proc(n) option remember; `if`(n<4, n, pi(n)-nops(factorset(n))+2) end:
b:= proc(t, n, k) option remember; local c, d, h;
elif k=2 and t=n then `if`(n<2, 0, phi(n))
for h from 1 to n-1 by d do
if igcd(t, h)=1 then c:= c +b(s(t*h, h), h, k-1) fi
mathematica: s[m_, r_] := s[m, r] = Product[If[i < r, i, 1], {i, FactorInteger[m][[All, 1]]}]; a[n_] := a[n] = If[n < 4, n, PrimePi[n]-Length[FactorInteger[n]]+2]; b[t_, n_, k_] := b[t, n, k] = Module[{c, d, h}, Which[k == 0 || k > n, 0, k == 1, 1, k == 2 && t == n, If[n < 2, 0, EulerPhi[n]], True, c = 0; d = 2-Mod[t, 2]; For[h = 1, h <= n-1, h = h+d, If[GCD[t, h] == 1, c = c+b[s[t*h, h], h, k-1] ] ]; c ] ]; t[n_, k_] := t[n, k] = b[s[n, n], n, k]+If[k == 0, 0, t[n, k-1]]; Table[Table[t[n, k], {k, 1, a[n]}], {n, 1, 20}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 19 2013, translated from Maple *)
xref: Rightmost elements of rows give A186973.
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 02 2011
